_prev_prog_3.Description:
Kingsburg Cogeneration Facility, Ammonia Injection System



Ammonia Storage and Delivery System used as Nox Reduction (SCR) System for combustion Gas Turbine. 



Facility is subject to CalARP/RMP/PSM Program Level 3.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention 



Kingsburg Cogeneration Facility has developed a Risk Management Program and an Emergency Response Plan to address CalARP Program requirements (19 CCR ?2735-2785).  

Kingsburg Cogeneration Facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia Injection System.  Kingsburg Cogeneration Facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 

The Kingsburg Cogeneration Facility is located at 11765 Mountainview, Kingsburg, California. 93631. The regulated substance at the Facility is anhydrous ammonia

The anhydrous ammonia stored on site is used for controlling concentration of oxides of nitrogen (NOx) in the combustion flue gas from the boiler unit.  This solution is volatilized into anhydrous ammonia vapor prior to injection into the boiler.  The anhydrous ammonia is consumed by the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system to convert NOx emissions into nitrogen and water.

The maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia inventory in the ammonia injection system at the facility is 9600 gallons (54,720 lbs.).  The amount of anhydrous ammonia corresponds to the 80% capacity of the ammonia storage tank, as the facility implements administrative controls that limit the maximum filling of the tank to 80% of the capacity. 



Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis

Per CalARP Regulations and US EPA RMP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for the Ammonia Injection System.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment tab of the 2014 Five Year Update Binder. 

?Alternative Release Sc

enario Results Summary:

An alternative release scenario was modeled.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment tab of the 2014  Five Year Update Binder.



Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Kingsburg Cogeneration Facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent.  Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).



In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release, including the following:

?Well Designed Relief System

?Ammonia Detection, two detectors located in the ammonia storage tank area and one detector located in the Skid area.

? Ammonia Alarms. There are two alarms; one is located inside the power house and a second alarm is located on the Distribution Control System (DCS).

?Deluge System located on top of the ammonia storage tank.

?Safety Showers/Eyewash Stations are available for Operators, if exposed to ammonia at the below locations.

oSouth-west corner of Control Emissions Management System (CEMS) building and one by Auxiliary MCC.

oInside /outside Power House east wall

?Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used

by plant personnel, as necessary, such as; full face respirators in individuals lockers and SCBA 1, are located in the control room and in the conference room]

?The system undergoes periodic maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.





Accidental Release Prevention Program 

As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Kingsburg Cogeneration Facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The total anhydrous ammonia inventory of the ammonia injection system at the facility is 9600 gallons (54,720 lbs.).  The amount of anhydrous ammonia corresponds to the 80% capacity of the ammonia storage tank, as the facility implements administrative controls that limit the maximum filling of the tanks to 80% of the capacity. 



Therefore, the covered process has over the 10,000-lb threshold quantity for US EPA RMP and Cal/OSHA PSM threshold quantities, and over the 500-lb state threshold for CalARP Program.  As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3, US EPA RMP Program Level 3, and Cal/OSHA PSM.  



The Anhydrous Ammonia Prevention Program 3 elements include:

?    Process Safety Information

?    Process Hazard Analysis

?    Operating Procedures

?    Training

?    Mechanical Integrity

?    Management of Change

?    Pre-Startup Safety Review

?    Compliance Audits

?    Incident Investigation

?    Employee Participation

?    Hot Work Permit

?    Contractors

In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in Section 4.7 of this document. 



Five-Year Accident History 

For any accidental release meeting the five-year accident history reporting criteria of 19 CCR ?2750.9, the owner or operator shall submit the data required under 19 CCR ?2745.5, ?2745.6, and ?2745.7 with respect to that

accident within six months of the release or by the time the RMP is updated under 19 CCR ?2745.10, whichever is earlier.

From 19 CCR ?2750.9: 

The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of ammonia at Kingsburg Cogeneration Facility in the past five years.



Emergency Response Program

Kingsburg Cogeneration Facility is not a First Responder Facility.  The Facility has implemented an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that meets the requirements of 8 CCR ?3220 and does not assume the role of first responder during an emergency.  Employees are trained to evacuate and call 9-1-1.  The Kingsburg Cogeneration Facility will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders.  They are trained and fully equipped to respond to hazardous material releases  



Kingsburg Cogeneration Facility maintain the Business Emergency Plan (BEP) that provides the response protocols and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which have been implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  The BEP is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with CalARP and EAP regulations. 



Key elements of the BEP include:

?Emergency Alarm Procedures

?Evacuation Procedures

?Safety and Health Considerations

?Notification Procedure

Planned Changes To Improve Safety 

The PHA study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the May 5, 2014 PHA Report located behind the PHA Tab of the 2014 Five-Year Update Binder.
